content:
Attachment I Audit Report No. A-1711
Audit Report - Details
III. FINDINGS:
A. Background:
The excess property program is divided into project type and non-project type according to their purposes and sources of fund. The project type excess property program has been carried out since FY1958 mainly under the project No. 484-99-471, and by other divisions of the Mission for other projects, e.g., vocational schools. The specific target of the project is to further advance the AID-financed program in Taiwan by providing equipment and materials from U.S. Government excess stocks, which can be made available at low cost for the economic develop- ment of Taiwan. This project has a direct bearing on the pro- jects undertaken by the recipients inasmuch as sizable savings in cost of project implementation can be effected. CUSA 2nd Division is responsible for project type excess property program and Bureau of Engineering Service (BES) is the handling agency taking care of the delivery and storage services of excess pro- perty.
In FY60 & 61 three PAS (Nos. 0219, 0220 & 1206) were issued for the acquisition of excess property on a non-project basis. This portion of the program has attempted to import groups of equipment known to be required by certain industries or organiza- tions, which have then been designated as eligible to bid. There are two principal methods of acquiring excess property under the non-project portion of the program. One is by direct request (through US AID/C to the depot where the equipment is located) for items seen in the General Services Administration (GSA) bulletins. The other is by on-the-spot acquisition by US AID/C and GRC teams which visit various military depots on Taiwan. CUSA 3rd Division is dealing with the non-project type excess property program and the Central Trust of China (CTC) and Taiwan Supply Bureau (TSB) are designated as handling agencies for storage and auction of excess property.
On February 20, 1962, the US AID/C Program Officer conducted an observation on the status of excess property stored in BES yard and TSB warehouse. Some deficiencies found as a result of observation wore indicated in the PO letter No. MC-2747 addressed to CUSA on 2/20/62 as shown in Attachment I-A. Subsequently, P/SP checked the storage status of BES and reported to PO per its momo dated 2/26/62 as shown in Attachment II-B. This review has the intention of ascertaining whether the CUSA handling proce- dures of the arrival and disposal of excess property are appro- priato. Pertinent files in P/SP and CUSA were reviewed, and Messrs. C. S. Kan of CUSA/2D and SY Tan of CUSA 3D were contactos,
B. Project type excess property:
1. Arrival and allocation: The procurement and allocation are made on the basis of JGWhite recommendations. The property procured under this project is allocated to designated sponsors of aid-financed projects. Such property may not be sold at auction. Upon arrival, the bill of lading is forwarded to BES by CUSA 3D. BES is responsible for taking delivery at the port of entry. The properties are then stored in BES yard. After properties arrived at BES yard,

paragraphs.content: Attachment I Audit Report No. A-1711

The excess property program is divided into project type and non-project type according to their purposes and sources of fund. The project type excess property program has been carried out since FY1958 mainly under the project No. 484-99-471, and by other divisions of the Mission for other projects, e.g., vocational schools. The specific target of the project is to further advance the AID-financed program in Taiwan by providing equipment and materials from U.S. Government excess stocks, which can be made available at low cost for the economic develop- ment of Taiwan. This project has a direct bearing on the pro- jects undertaken by the recipients inasmuch as sizable savings in cost of project implementation can be effected. CUSA 2nd Division is responsible for project type excess property program and Bureau of Engineering Service (BES) is the handling agency taking care of the delivery and storage services of excess pro- perty.

In FY60 & 61 three PAS (Nos. 0219, 0220 & 1206) were issued for the acquisition of excess property on a non-project basis. This portion of the program has attempted to import groups of equipment known to be required by certain industries or organiza- tions, which have then been designated as eligible to bid. There are two principal methods of acquiring excess property under the non-project portion of the program. One is by direct request (through US AID/C to the depot where the equipment is located) for items seen in the General Services Administration (GSA) bulletins. The other is by on-the-spot acquisition by US AID/C and GRC teams which visit various military depots on Taiwan. CUSA 3rd Division is dealing with the non-project type excess property program and the Central Trust of China (CTC) and Taiwan Supply Bureau (TSB) are designated as handling agencies for storage and auction of excess property.

On February 20, 1962, the US AID/C Program Officer conducted an observation on the status of excess property stored in BES yard and TSB warehouse. Some deficiencies found as a result of observation wore indicated in the PO letter No. MC-2747 addressed to CUSA on 2/20/62 as shown in Attachment I-A. Subsequently, P/SP checked the storage status of BES and reported to PO per its momo dated 2/26/62 as shown in Attachment II-B. This review has the intention of ascertaining whether the CUSA handling proce- dures of the arrival and disposal of excess property are appro- priato. Pertinent files in P/SP and CUSA were reviewed, and Messrs. C. S. Kan of CUSA/2D and SY Tan of CUSA 3D were contactos,

1. Arrival and allocation: The procurement and allocation are made on the basis of JGWhite recommendations. The property procured under this project is allocated to designated sponsors of aid-financed projects. Such property may not be sold at auction. Upon arrival, the bill of lading is forwarded to BES by CUSA 3D. BES is responsible for taking delivery at the port of entry. The properties are then stored in BES yard.
